Situation1: Laundry needs to be done so clean clothes are available for the family’s activities.
Situation2: A patient with a chronic autoimmune disease requires a very specific and ongoing treatment plan.
Story: I stared at the overflowing laundry basket, the colors and whites tangled together, a silent reminder of the promise I made to my husband last night: “I’ll get the laundry done before your big meeting tomorrow.” He’d smiled, grateful, and I’d felt the warmth of being needed at home. But now, my phone buzzed with a message from the clinic—Mrs. Patel’s bloodwork had come in, and her autoimmune disease was flaring again. She needed a new treatment plan, and I was the only doctor on call who knew her case well enough to adjust her medications safely. My mind raced with the weight of both worlds: the expectation to keep our home running smoothly, to be a reliable partner, and the responsibility to my patient, whose health depended on my expertise and timely intervention. I felt the pressure building, my heart caught between the hum of the washing machine and the urgent ping of my medical app, each demanding my full attention, each unwilling to wait.
